concept: Engineered allosteric mutations in GT-B fold glycosyltransferases can create molecular switches that discretely toggle between linear and branched polysaccharide synthesis modes through single amino acid substitutions. This approach may enable rapid exploration of diverse synthetic cell wall polymer architectures without extensive pathway reconstruction, potentially accelerating biomaterials research and therapeutic applications.

rationale.statement: The bi-lobal, Rossmann-like domain architecture of GT-B fold glycosyltransferases provides an ideal structural foundation for allosteric engineering. The central hinge region between domains allows mutations to exploit inter-domain flexibility and induce conformational changes that alter substrate orientation. This mechanistic elasticity enables control over acceptor positioning for either linear elongation or branched chain formation without disrupting core catalytic function.

Discrete functional switching through single amino acid substitutions is empirically validated in GT-B enzymes. A rational engineering study of the C-glycosyltransferase GgCGT demonstrated that a single G389K mutation switched the enzyme from two-step di-C-glycosylation to single-step mono-C-glycosylation. This direct precedent, combined with theoretical models showing bistable conformational landscapes in GT-B enzymes, establishes the mechanistic plausibility of engineered molecular toggles.

Rational design strategies have proven successful in modifying glycosyltransferase specificity and generating novel product architectures. Docking-guided engineering has identified mutational hot spots that expand donor preferences in GT enzymes, while mutational analyses in related transferase families demonstrate the technical feasibility of creating allosteric switches through targeted amino acid substitutions.

Robust experimental frameworks exist to produce, characterize, and validate engineered GT-B switches. Expression strategies utilizing molecular chaperones and periplasmic localization ensure proper folding and stability. Cell-free biosynthesis platforms eliminate cellular interference, enabling precise quantification of switching behavior through high-throughput assays and comprehensive biophysical characterization.

This engineering approach offers significant scientific impact by enabling efficient exploration of polysaccharide diversity through minimal genetic modifications. Controllable branching patterns in synthetic cell wall polymers directly influence material properties crucial for biomaterials applications, host-pathogen interaction studies, and advanced therapeutic delivery systems, while bypassing the complexity and time requirements of extensive pathway reconstruction.
